raw_text:
Jones files lawsuit against Conte
 
 Marion Jones has filed a lawsuit for defamation against Balco boss Victor Conte following his allegations that he gave her performance-enhancing drugs.
 
 The Sydney Olympic gold medallist says Conte damaged her reputation and she is seeking $25m (£13m) in the suit. Conte, whose company is at the centre of a doping investigation, made the claims in a US television programme. He and three others were indicted in February by a federal grand jury for a variety of alleged offences. In an email to the Associated Press on Wednesday, Conte said: "I stand by everything I said". Jones won three gold medals and two bronzes in Sydney in 2000. Her lawsuit, filed in the US District Court in San Francisco, said the sprinter had passed a lie detector test and that she "has never taken banned performance-enhancing drugs". Conte's statements, the suit added, were "false and malicious". After the ABC television program earlier this month, Jones' lawyer Richard Nicholls said: "Marion has steadfastly maintained her position throughout: she has never, ever used performance-enhancing drugs. "Victor Conte is a man facing a 42-count federal indictment, while Marion Jones is one of America's most decorated female athletes. Mr Conte's statements have been wildly contradictory. "Mr Conte chose to make unsubstantiated allegations on television, while Marion Jones demanded to take and then passed a lie detector examination.
 
 "Mr Conte is simply not credible. We challenge him to submit to the same lie detector procedure that Marion Jones passed." The sport's ruling body, the IAAF, is taking a cautious approach to Conte's allegations but contacted the US Anti-Doping Agency. Communications director Nick Davies said the IAAF would seek to contact Conte "for further information". But Davies stressed it would be up to the American authorities to decide whether they will take action against Jones in light of Conte's television interview and the world governing body would monitor the situation closely. "If it is felt there is case to answer, it would be for its national governing body (USA Track and Field) to take the appropriate disciplinary action," he added. "The US Anti-Doping Agency has proved itself to be very diligent in its anti-doping war. "And I am sure, like ourselves, they will be watching the television programme with great interest." Jones, who is under investigation for steroid use by the US Anti-Doping Agency, has continually denied ever taking illegal substances since being investigated in the Balco scandal, although she praised a zinc supplement Conte marketed. Jones, who did not win any medals in Athens in August, has never failed a drugs test. Meanwhile, Conte, who has been charged along with three other men of distributing illegal steroids and money laundering, is due to face trial in March.
llama3.2:1b: Jones files lawsuit against Conte for defamation. Conte made allegations that Jones used performance-enhancing drugs, which she denies. A US television programme featured Conte's claims, but he stands by them. Jones alleges Conte damaged her reputation with his statements. The IAAF will monitor the situation and consider taking action if they deem there is enough evidence.
llama3.2:3b: Marion Jones files $25m lawsuit against Victor Conte over allegations he gave her performance-enhancing drugs, saying his statements are false and malicious, and she passed a lie detector test.
gemma2:2b: Marion Jones filed a defamation lawsuit against Victor Conte for his allegations that she used performance-enhancing drugs.  Conte made these claims on TV after being indicted on charges related to doping. Jones denies ever using performance-enhancers, has passed a lie detector test, and is seeking $25 million in damages. The IAAF and USADA are monitoring the situation.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Marion Jones filed a defamation lawsuit against Balco boss Victor Conte over allegations that he gave her performance-enhancing drugs. The Sydney Olympic gold medallist claims Conte damaged her reputation and seeks compensation totaling $25 million. Conte denies using performance-enhancing drugs, calling the allegations "false and malicious." Despite Conte's statements being widely contradicted by Jones' lawyer, the IAAF is hesitant to take action against him.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Marion Jones sues Victor Conte over doping claims following his TV interview allegations against her, seeking $25m in damages. Conte denies these claims but faces 42-count federal indictment for doping violations. Jones' lawyer challenges Conte's credibility by demanding a lie detector test after a television program. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) contacts the US Anti-Doping Agency cautiously while monitoring Conte's trial and Conte's statement on TV.
qwen2.5:3b: Marion Jones, an Olympic gold medalist, has filed a defamation lawsuit against Victor Conte, the owner of a company linked to doping allegations. Jones claims Conte damaged her reputation by making false accusations about giving her performance-enhancing drugs, while she denies ever using banned substances. Jones passed a lie detector test and is demanding $25m in damages. The case involves Jones' continued denial of doping despite prior investigations and Conte's indictment for his role in the doping scandal. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) remains cautious but intends to cooperate with US Anti-Doping Agency (USADA). The USADA will decide if Jones should face disciplinary action, depending on the outcome of Conte's television interview.
opencoder:1.5b:
Jones files lawsuit against Marion, a gold medalist in Olympic sport.

Marion Jones has filed a suit for defamation against Victor Conte who allegedly damaged the reputation of Balco and claimed that he gave her performance-enhancing drugs.

Conte, who owns a company known as DoT, made several accusations involving the US television programme. Indicted in February, he was indicted for a range of alleged offenses.

On Wednesday, Conte said: "I stand by everything I said. He has been accused of false and malicious accusations. After ABC, he has not taken banned performance-enhancing drugs."

After the ABC television program earlier this month, Jones' lawyer Richard Nicholls maintained that Marion's stance remained unaltered.

The case was announced by the IAAF, the agency responsible for anti-doping investigations. The agency had confirmed that they have proved to be very diligent in its investigation and enforcement of anti-doping laws.

Jones has consistently denied ever taking illegal drugs and claims that she "has never taken banned performance-enhancing drugs." She praised a zinc supplement Conte made, but it did not stop Conte's charges. It appears Jones is well-versed in the world governing body's stance on steroid use.

In contrast to other athletes, Jones has never been caught trying to pass a lie detector examination, unlike the sport's ruling body, which admitted that Conte had made unsubstantiated accusations on television.

However, the case between Jones and Marion is not resolved. The investigation is ongoing by the IAAF and the American authorities to decide whether they will take action against Jones in light of the evidence presented. With the agency monitoring closely, it is clear that there are cases pending.

Jones' lawyer Richard Nicholls said: "I stand by everything I said". Jones won three gold medals and two bronzes in Sydney 2000. Conte's statements, the suit added, were "false and malicious". After the ABC television program earlier this month, Jones' lawyer Richard Nicholls said: "Marion has steadfastly maintained her position throughout: she has never, ever used performance-enhancing drugs. "Mr Conte's statements have been wildly contradictory. "Mr Conte chose to make unsubstantiated allegations on television, while Marion Jones is one of America's most decorated female athletes." Mr Conte's statements have been widely criticized by sports experts and the media. The US Anti-Doping Agency (USADA) has taken a cautious approach to Conte's allegations but contacted the IAAF for further information. Communications director Nick Davies said the IAAF would seek to contact Conte "for further information". But Davies stressed it would be up to the American authorities to decide whether they will take action against Jones in light of Conte's television interview and the world governing body would monitor the situation closely.
 
 "Mr Conte is simply not credible," said Nick Davies, communications director at the IAAF. "We challenge him to submit to the same lie detector procedure that Marion Jones passed." The USADA has proved itself to be very diligent in its anti-doping war. And I am sure, like ourselves, they will be watching the television program with great interest.

The USADA has previously taken action against Conte for his alleged use of steroids and money laundering in 2003. But the agency has not taken action against Jones since then.

"Meanwhile, Conte, who has been charged along with three other men of distributing illegal steroids and money laundering, is due to face trial in March."  "Jones' lawyer Richard Nicholls said: 'I stand by everything I said'. Jones won three gold medals and two bronzes in Sydney 2000."

 "Jones has consistently denied ever using performance-enhancing drugs," said Nick Davies. "We challenge Conte's allegations of giving her performance-enhancing drugs by the USADA."

The suit claims that Conte made false and malicious statements about the athlete, who was anointed as America's most decorated female athlete. Jones, who won three gold medals and two bronze medals in Sydney in 2000, alleges that Conté passed a lie detector test while making unsustantiated allegations of his own. The suit also claims that he made false and malicious statements to the Associated Press about the athlete's conduct. After a US television program earlier this month, Jones' lawyer argued that Conté "chose to make wildly contradictory" statements about drugs usage in sports. Jones demanded to take and then passed a lie detector examination. The sporting body, the IAAF, has taken a cautionary approach to Conte's allegations but contacted US Anti-Doping Agency for further information. Meanwhile, Jones is facing trial on suspicion of distributing steroids while being investigated by US Anti-Dopping Authority.
